title: Rachel Ah Koy
text:
Rachel Ah Koy (born May 31, 1989) is a <a href="Fiji">Fiji Islander</a> <a href="swimmer">swimmer</a>. She is the granddaughter of businessman, politician, and diplomat <a href="James%20Ah%20Koy">Sir James Ah Koy</a>.
She competed in the <a href="2002%20Commonwealth%20Games">2002 Commonwealth Games</a>, setting a <a href="List%20of%20Fiji%20records%20in%20swimming">national record</a> in the women's 50 metres <a href="breaststroke">breaststroke</a>, with a time of 34.99 sec. during the qualifiers, and a national record in the women's 100 m breaststroke heats, with a time of 1:17.33. Ah Koy also competed in the <a href="2006%20Commonwealth%20Games">2006 Commonwealth Games</a>; she qualified for the semi-finals in both the 50 m and 100 m events, but failed to reach the finals.
Ah Koy won a silver medal in the women's 200m individual <a href="medley%20%28music%29">medley</a> at the 2003 <a href="South%20Pacific%20Games">South Pacific Games</a>, at the age of 14, behind New Caledonia's <a href="Diane%20Bui%20Duyet">Diane Bui Duyet</a> and ahead of fellow Fiji Islander <a href="Caroline%20Pickering">Caroline Pickering</a>. Ah Koy won gold in the women's 100m breaststroke. She also competed in the 2007 South Pacific Games, winning a silver medal in the women's 200m individual medley, behind New Caledonia's <a href="Lara%20Grangeon">Lara Grangeon</a>.
She was invited by the Fiji Swimming Association to seek a qualifying spot to <a href="Fiji%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics">represent Fiji</a> at the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>, but declined, citing her time-consuming studies at <a href="Otago%20University">Otago University</a> in <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>.
